Guangxi University 100# Daxue road Nanning Guangxi Province 530004 PR China Graphical abstract The reaction of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates requires high-performance, low-cost, and facilely recycled catalysts. Here, we report a heterogeneous catalyst (MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br) based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for catalytic CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates. The MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst was prepared as follows: A MOFs precursor (MIL-101-NH2) was firstly synthesized using a method of hydrothermal synthesis, then coupled with the quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquid (N(BzBnme2)Br) via aldehyde-amide condensation. A series of comparative experiments revealed that MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst has high activity for catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction to produce cyclic carbonates in the absence of solvents and co-catalysts. As was exampled by the synthesis of propylene carbonate, a high yield (93 %) and selectivity (99 %) was achieved under the optimized conditions (0.93 mol% MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst, 1.4 MPa CO2 pressure, 17 mmol propylene oxide, 100 °C, 5 h). More impressive, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst could be recycled easily by filtration and was reusable up to several times without a significant activity decay. Furthermore, our density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that such high catalytic activity mainly resulted from the cooperative catalysis between the coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ sites and Br anions in MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst. Meanwhile, a possible mechanism for the cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst was also proposed. Keywords Cycloaddition reaction Cyclic carbonate Metal-organic framework Ionic liquid MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br DFT calculations 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is one of the exhaust gases produced by human activities, and its excessive emission is considered to cause global warming for the past decades [1–3]. However, it is undeniable that CO2 is also an ideal carbon feedstock for synthesizing various valuable chemicals owing to its intrinsic property (like abundant reserves, low cost, and hypotoxicity) [4–6]. Carbon dioxide could be used as a substrate to synthesize many useful chemicals such as formic [7,8], methane [9,10], urea [11], methanol [12–14], hydrocarbon fuels [15], dimethyl carbonate [16], oxazolidinone [17], cyclic carbonates [18]. One of the most representative examples of CO2 utilization is the synthesis of cyclic carbonate by coupling CO2 with epoxides [19–24]. The resulting products can be used as important raw materials for the synthesis of plastics or many fine chemicals, and as nonprotic solvents or degreaser [25]. For efficiently catalytic CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates, much effort has been devoted to the development of high-performance catalysts in the past decades [26,27]. These have resulted in the identification of a number of active catalysts, including homogeneous materials (like ionic liquids, nitrogen-containing polymers, organocatalysts) and heterogeneous materials (like metal-salen complexes, metal-organic frameworks, molecular sieves) [28–32]. Generally, homogeneous catalysts showed much higher catalytic efficiency compared to heterogeneous catalysts, mainly due to its higher percentage of active site utilization [33]. Among the homogeneous catalysts, ionic liquids (ILs) have significant catalytic effects, especially for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides [34–37]. The anion in ILs could promote the ring-opening of the epoxide, and the CO2 couples with the ring-opened epoxide to form ring closure of the final product. More importantly, when ILs are used as a catalyst, good results can be achieved without adding co-catalysts. Nevertheless, homogeneous catalysts possess significant disadvantages over heterogeneous catalysts on separation, purification, and cyclic reusability [38,39]. In this regard, catalytic CO2 conversion using heterogeneous catalysts appears to be more realistic for the industrial production of cyclic carbonates. Therefore, it is very important to graft ILs on a carrier to develop highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts for catalyzing CO2 conversion. Thus, it has been established several efficient syntheses of IL-based porous heterogeneous catalysts [40–46]. In our previous work, we also found that the triethanolamine-modified mesoporous SBA-15 is an effective catalyst for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. But its required temperature and CO2 pressure are relatively high [47]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have become one of the most widely used catalysts in heterogeneous catalysis due to its many advantages [48–50]. MOFs are composed of metal ions and organic ligands and has an excellent internal structure [51,52]. With a unique structure, MOFs have organic and inorganic hybrid properties [53]. In recent years, MOFs have also become a promising heterogeneous catalyst to fixing CO2 [54]. Moreover, the incorporation of coordinatively unsaturated metal known as Lewis acids active sites in MOFs would be significantly beneficial for catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides [55–57]. But this process catalyzed by MOFs catalysts typically required high pressures (>2 MPa) as well as indispensable co-catalysts (like tetrabutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr)) [58,59]. In our previous work, we found that defective UiO-66-NH2 (Zr/Ce) can catalyze the synthesis of propylene carbonate [60]. Although this catalyst can achieve higher yields under mild conditions, it is still necessary to add a co-catalyst. The use of co-catalysts would also greatly increase the cost of production in terms of both energy and capital input. Therefore, there is still an urgent need to develop new heterogeneous catalysts based on IL-MOFs, which can efficiently catalyze CO2 conversion under mild and co-catalyst free conditions. We prepared a new type of MOFs-based heterogeneous catalysts (MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br) by combining MIL-101-NH2 with ionic liquid (N(BzBnme2)Br) through aldehyde-amide condensation. The catalyst has the advantages of simple synthesis conditions and low catalytic cycloaddition reaction temperature. The synthesis (Fig. S1) and grafting (Scheme 2) of the ionic liquid were carried out by simple stirring at room temperature. When synthesizing other similar catalysts, the reaction conditions are more complicated [61,62]. In addition, the cycloaddition reaction temperature is 100 °C, and the yield of propylene carbonate is already at a relatively high level. Due to the synergistic effects of the multifunctional sites, the obtained material exhibits high TOF value under mild and co-catalyst free conditions. In other words, a high-efficiency catalyst synthesized by a simple method can perform a catalytic reaction at a relatively low temperature. Due to MIL-101-NH2 nanoparticles have no obvious acute and subacute toxicity, the toxicity of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br is also smaller than other catalysts [63]. Therefore, from the perspective of saving resources and protecting the environment, it is very meaningful to study this catalyst. Furthermore, our density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that the coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ sites and Br anions in MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst work in concert provide synergistic active sites for the cycloaddition reaction. Meanwhile, the possible mechanism of the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction was also proposed. 2 Experiment 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of MIL-101-NH2 According to the previously reported literature [64], MIL-101-NH2 could be synthesized with a little modification (Scheme 1 ). Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (800 mg, 2 mmol), NH2-BDC (360 mg, 2 mmol), and NaOH (200 mg, 5 mmol) were dispersed in deionized water (15 mL), respectively. The resulting solutions were then mixed and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Subsequently, a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave that contains the above-mixed solution is kept at 150 °C for 12 h, and then let it cool to the room temperature naturally. After the reaction, the green precipitate was obtained, it was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF three times, and then was activated in an autoclave at 100 °C for 12 h using ethanol as solvent. Thus obtained solid was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h. 2.1.2 Synthesis MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br N(BzBnme2)Br was prepared and characterized (Fig. S1). The synthesis process of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br is shown in Scheme 2 . To a solution of N(BzBnme2)Br (320 mg, 1 mmol) in methanol (30 mL) was added MIL-101-NH2 (532 mg). The solution was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After removing the solvent by centrifugation, it was purified by washing with ether several times and dried in a vacuum oven for 12 h to obtain a white solid. 2.2 Catalytic performance evaluation The 50 ml high-pressure stainless steel autoclave was a reactor used in the cycloaddition reaction, equipped with a mechanical stirrer and system temperature. In order to eliminate the influence of water on the cycloaddition reaction, the catalyst was dried at 100 °C for 4 h before the cycloaddition reaction. Before adding the PO and the required catalyst to the reactor, it was purged with CO2 and vented 3 times. After the reactor was sealed, turn on the stirring device (400 rpm) while increasing the carbon dioxide pressure and temperature to the set value. After the set time has elapsed, the temperature of the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, and then the residual carbon dioxide pressure was gradually reduced. The gas chromatograph (GC-2010plus) analyses the organic phase obtained by filtration and centrifugation. Because it is equipped with an FID and a DB-624 capillary column (30 m ×0.32 mm ×1.8 μm), the organic phase can be identified and quantitatively analyzed. 2.3 Theoretical calculations The Gaussian 09 packet of the M06−2X [65] and B3LYP-D3BJ [66] and B3LYP [67] correlation functions implemented DFT calculations, respectively. The basis sets employed were the 6−31+G(d) for carbon atoms, hydrogen atoms, oxygen atoms, and nitrogen atoms, and the LANL2DZ for chromium atoms and bromine atoms to calculate the geometries and frequencies. Considering that the 5-coordinated Cr centers are the active sites in MIL-101-NH2, a single repeating unit was chosen as the calculation model for simplicity. To confirm that the transition state only connects the two required minimum values, the minimum energy path (MEP) is constructed by the intrinsic reaction coordinate analysis (IRC) method. In addition, to obtain more reliable energies, single-point energy calculations were performed on the key geometries by using B3LYP/6−311+g(2df,p)&&SDD, B3LYP-D3BJ/6-311+g(2df,p)&&SDD and M06−2X/6−311+g(2df,p)&&SDD, respectively. The energy of the corresponding complex is set to be zero point to evaluate the energy barrier, which is also corrected by ZPE, ΔE(energy barrier) = E(transition state) − E(corresponding complex) + ΔZPE. The relative energy is calculated with respect to the sum of isolated reactant and catalyst corrected by ZPE, ΔE(relative energy) = E(transition state/complex) − [E(reactant) + E(catalyst)] +ΔZPE. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of catalyst samples As illustrated in Schemes 1–2Scheme 1, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst sample was prepared using a two-step method. Firstly, the MIL-101-NH2 was generated from NH2-BDC and Cr(NO3)3·9H2O under the solvothermal conditions. The obtained sample was then decorated with quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquid (N(BzBnme2)Br) via amine-aldehyde condensation to prepare the targeted catalyst. Morphology observation of the hydrothermal sample by SEM and TEM showed an irregular particle structure with an average size of 100 nm (Fig. 1 a-d). The XRD analysis of these irregular particles (Fig. 2 ) found that all the main diffraction peaks were in basic agreement with that of simulated Cr-MIL-101, indicating a similar crystalline structure of hydrothermal sample compared with Cr-MIL-101. The observed rather broad Bragg reflections suggested a poorly crystalline product consisting of small nanoparticles (∼50 nm), which was in accordance with the previous reports [68]. The formation of -NH2 functional MIL-101-NH2 during the hydrothermal process was further evidenced by FT-IR spectra analysis. As shown in Fig. 3 , the hydrothermal sample clearly presented the characteristic bands of -NH2 groups in MIL-101-NH2 at 3459, 3363, 2930, and 1658 cm–1 [69–71]. After the amine-aldehyde condensation, XRD patterns of the targeted catalyst showed the diffraction peaks are consistent with that of MIL-101-NH2. This indicated that MIL-101-NH2 precursor when decorated with N(BzBnme2)Br undergoes no crystal structure change. SEM and TEM observation found that the sample was well preserved with irregular particle morphology (Fig. 1). The parallel EDS mapping showed a homogeneous distribution of Cr, N, and Br elements on the sample surface (Fig. 1e-h). This, together with the observation of a new Br element signal in the EDS spectrum of the targeted catalyst, implies the successful incorporation of bromine-containing ionic liquid onto MIL-101-NH2 precursor (Fig. 4 ). Evidence supporting the coupling of MIL-101-NH2 precursor with N(BzBnme2)Br was further obtained from the FT-IR spectra and XPS analyses. As seen in Fig. 3c, the FT-IR spectrum of the targeted catalyst showed a weakened -NH2 characteristic signal and an additional CN double bond (CN) peak at around 1619 cm−1 [72]. Evidently, the CN double bond was formed from the condensation reaction of the NH2 group in MIL-101-NH2 and the CHO in quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquid. According to the XPS full-spectrum scanning results, the Cr, C, O, and N element signals are clearly identified in the MIL-101-NH2 precursor sample, and a new additional characteristic peak of the Br element can be easily seen in the targeted catalyst sample (Fig. 5 a). Meanwhile, the XPS Br 3d spectrum of the targeted catalyst shows a predominant bromide anion signal at the binding energy of 67.00 eV, which was negatively shifted by 0.45 eV relative to that of Br signal in C7H7Br (Fig. 5b) [73,74]. These results clearly corroborated the quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquid (N(BzBnme2)Br) successfully grafting onto MIL-101-NH2 to form the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst. The IL loading content was measured by elemental analysis. Based on the change of the carbon and nitrogen element of MIL-101-NH2 precursor before and after the amine-aldehyde condensation reaction, the loading amount of ILs on the targeted catalyst was determined to be 0.34 mmol g−1. The specific surface area and pore structure of MIL-101-NH2 and MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br were further investigated by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms. As seen in Fig. 6 , the MIL-101-NH2 and MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br samples both exhibited type IV isotherm and a hysteresis loop of type H3, which are characteristic for a mesoporous architecture [75]. Based on the isotherm, the MIL-101-NH2 precursor possessed a narrow pore size distribution centered at 2.2 nm and a high specific surface area (SSA) of 803 m² g−1. After reacting with N(BzBnme2)Br via the amine-aldehyde condensation reaction, the sample displayed a decrease of both pore size and SSA. Evidently, this phenomenon should come from the reaction of MIL-101-NH2 precursor and quaternary ammonium salt ILs, resulting in the pore of MIL-101-NH2 precursor partially occupied by the ILs functional groups. Similar results had been reported by previous research [76]. Even so, the obtained MIL-101-N(Bnme2) Br sample still possessed open pores with a size of 2.07 nm and a high SSA of 546 m² g−1, which would facilitate the diffusion of the reactants and products. Meanwhile, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br showed favorable thermal stability at high temperatures. According to TGA results (Fig. 7 ), MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br samples were initially decomposed at a temperature of ∼320 °C, which was even higher than that of MIL-101-NH2 precursor. This result suggested the as-prepared MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst could be used as a heterogeneous catalyst for catalytic CO2 conversion at a relatively high temperature. Here, the first stage weight loss of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst below the temperature of ∼320 °C should originate from the volatilization of water and solvent [77]. As shown in Fig.S2 and Fig.S3, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br is decomposed into Cr2O3. 3.2 Catalytic performance The synthesis process of propylene carbonate is shown in Scheme 3 . In the absence of co-catalyst and solvent-free conditions, the effect of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br on the cycloaddition reaction of carbon dioxide and epoxides to synthesize cyclic carbonates was evaluated. Catalytic conditions were at 100 °C for 5 h, using 1.4 MPa CO2 pressure and 17 mmol epoxides. To investigate the catalytic activity, propylene oxide (PO) was selected as the reaction substrate to react with carbon dioxide. For comparison, MIL-101-NH2 precursor, N(BzBnme2)Br, and the physical mixture of MIL-101-NH2 and N(BzBnme2)Br were also measured under identical conditions. As listed in Table 1 , propylene carbonate was not obtained without catalyst (entry 1, Table 1). Upon the presence of the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst, a remarkable increase in the yield of propylene carbonate (PC, 93 %) was achieved (entry 2, Table 1). In sharp contrast, the sole MIL-101-NH2 precursor (entry 3, Table 1) and N(BzBnme2)Br (entry 4, Table 1) exhibited very low catalytic efficiency with a yield of 35 % and 22 %, respectively. Even though the physical mixture of MIL-101-NH2 and (N(BzBnme2)Br) (entry 5, Table 1) showed excellent catalytic activity similar to the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst (entry 2, Table 1), their homogeneous nature severely hindered their separation and reusability. It should be mentioned that the selectivity for the synthesis of PC for all catalyst samples is always above 98 %. Here, the high catalytic activity of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst should be attributed to the synergistic effects of MIL-101-NH2 and N(BzBnme2)Br. This was validated by our theoretical calculation results as stated below. In order to determine the optimal reaction conditions for the production of cyclic carbonates, we further investigated the effects of reaction parameters including CO2 pressure, MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst amount, time, and temperature. The impact of the CO2 pressure is shown in Fig. 8 a. As the CO2 pressure increases from 1 MPa to 1.8 MPa, the yield of cyclic carbonate showed a volcano-like change and reached its maximum at 1.4 MPa. This result could be owed to that the solubility and concentration of CO2 in the liquid phase were enhanced by the increase in CO2 pressure, which would improve the interaction between the gas phase and the liquid phase, thereby increasing the yield of PC [78,79]. Nevertheless, when more acidic CO2 was dissolved in the liquid phase, which could cause the reaction system to appear CO2-epoxide complexing [80]. CO2-epoxide complexing was formed in the reaction system, resulting in a decrease in PO concentration in the liquid phase [61]. It can be seen from the calculation of DFT that the entire catalytic process mainly relies on the synergistic effect of the metal sites and anion sites of the catalyst. As the CO2 in the gas phase continues to increase, the CO2 concentration in the liquid phase will raise. The probability of contact between CO2 and the active sites of the catalyst will increase, resulting in an increase in the yield of PC. When the content of PO in the liquid phase decreases, the probability of contact between PO and the active sites of the catalyst will decrease, resulting in a decrease in the yield of PC. In the process of increasing CO2 pressure, it should be pointed out that the selectivity of PC was always higher than 99 %, which has nothing to do with the change of CO2 pressure. Similarly, the yield of PC also showed MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst amount dependence (Fig. 8b). Among the comparison experiments, the group with a catalyst amount loading of 0.93 mol% showed the highest PC yield with 93 %, showing that the more suitable catalyst amount of 0.93 mol% than other catalyst dosages. The decrease of PC yield with a catalyst loading of 1.05 mol% may due to the restriction of mass transfer in the MOFs pores in the presence of an excess catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8c, further comparison of the measurement found the time of reaction also exhibited a pronounced impact on the PC yield. The PC yield increased sharply from 72 % to 93 % with the reaction time increased from 2 h to 5 h. Extending the time to 10 h has no obvious promoting effect on PC yield. Therefore, 5 h was considered as an appropriate operating time for the cycloaddition. Additionally, the cycloaddition reaction is also significantly affected by the reaction temperature. As the temperature rose from 80 °C to 120 °C, the PC yield increased significantly, as shown in Fig. 8d. However, as the reaction temperature further increased, the conversion of PO did not increase. Obviously, the lower solubility of CO2 at higher temperatures is the cause of the phenomenon. The suitable temperature at 100 °C was hence adopted in the following research. From the perspective of environmental friendliness, the reproducibility of MIL-101-N (Bnme2) Br was also investigated under optimal conditions using PO as the substrate. After each recovery, the catalyst was washed with acetone and activated in a vacuum oven at 100 °C for 12 h. As shown in Fig.9 , after the catalyst was reused 5 times, the PO conversion rate and selectivity did not decrease significantly. The post-used catalyst was characterized by XRD (Fig.10 a) and FT-IR (Fig.10b) analyses. It was observed that the phase structure of the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst was well retained after the 5 times reusability test. These results indicated that the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst has high stability and can be used in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides to synthesize cyclic carbonates. To investigate the versatile applicability of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst in catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction of carbon dioxide and epoxides to synthesize cyclic carbonates, we further extended the scope to various epoxides (entries 1–5, Table 2 ). It can be seen that as the molecular size of epoxide increases, the yield of the corresponding cycloaddition products decreases. This can be interpreted as that the cycloaddition reaction might mainly occur in the mesoporous channels of the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst, which limits the diffusion of the larger molecular epoxides and thus resulting in a low reaction rate. The group using epoxy chloropropane as starting material showed a much higher yield of cyclic carbonates. This implies that the terminal epoxide with an electron-withdrawing group might be more beneficial to nucleophilic attack and thus facilitate the reaction. It should be noted that the corresponding cyclic carbonates with excellent selectivity were always higher than 97 %, regardless of the type of epoxide investigated, which further proved the versatility of the catalyst. It has been proved that MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br was an excellent heterogeneous catalyst, which can be used to synthesize cyclic carbonates without any co-catalyst. Few heterogeneous catalysts have good non-metal properties and can be used in the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides and carbon dioxide. The combination of porous catalysts with Lewis acid sites and ionic liquids with appropriate functional groups is considered to be the factor for high catalytic activity. We compared the catalytic performance of the previously reported heterogeneous catalyst with that of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br. According to reports, catalysts modified by quaternary ammonium ionic liquids, such as Cr-MIL-101/TBAB [81] was active catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction (entry 1, Table 3 ). Cr-MIL-101/TBAB showed a PC yield of 82 % with 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure at 90 °C, and the reaction time needs to be extended for 24 h. The previously reported heterogeneous catalysts with ionic liquid supported by MIL-101 as carrier including IL@MIL-101-SO3H [82], the reaction time needs to be extended for 24 h (entry 2, Table 3). It is reported that Meim-UiO-66 (entry 3, Table 3) and UiO-67-IL (entry 4, Table 3) are imidazolium-based ionic liquid modified catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction [62,83]. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the TOF value of the above catalysts was much lower than MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br (entries 5–6, Table 3). Due to the synergistic effect of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br with the multi-functional active sites, it has a higher turnover frequency under mild conditions. We utilized B3LYP/6−31+g(d)&&LANL2DZ and B3LYP/6−311+g(2df,p)&&SDD, B3LYP-D3BJ/6−31+g(d)&&LANL2DZ and B3LYP-D3BJ/6−311+g(2df,p)&&SDD, M06−2X/6−31+g(d)&&LANL2DZ and M06−2X/6−311+g(2df, p)&&SDD methods to optimize geometry and calculate the single-point energy (Table S1-S3). There is no bond breaking or bond formation in CO2 insertion, the energy barrier for this step is small [84–86]. According to the literature reports, the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxide has two transition states [86]. The first is the ring-opening step (from PO addition to Ring opening); the second is ring-closure step (CO2 insertion to Ring closure). As shown in Fig. 11 , the total energy of PO addition and CO2 insertion is initially preset to zero. The energy barriers of TS1 and TS2 were calculated using the above three functions, respectively. The calculated results showed that the energy barrier of TS1 calculated by the M06−2X function is 6.95 kcal/mol (Fig. 11a), and the energy barriers calculated by the other two functions are 1.86 kcal/mol and 1.89 kcal/mol (Fig. 11b, c), respectively. Since TS1 is the transition state, the corresponding energy barrier should be relatively high. The energy barrier calculated by using M06−2X is more in line with the actual situation. Moreover, the energy barrier of the TS2 calculated by M06−2X is 10.05 kcal/mol (Fig. 11d), and the reaction energy barriers calculated by the other two functions are 22.30 kcal/mol and 23.39 kcal/mol (Fig. 11e f), the latter two cases are significantly higher than the former. Hence, only the TS2 calculated by B3LYP and B3LYP-D3BJ has a higher energy barrier, indicating that there is only one transition state calculated by using the two functions of B3LYP and B3LYP-D3BJ. Therefore, M06−2X is more suitable for the geometry optimization and the energy calculation of the catalyst reaction process. In comparison, vibration frequencies of different transition states (Figure S4-S7 S9-S12 S14-S17), the transition state optimized by M06−2X has the largest virtual frequency. This indicates that the transition state found by this function is more reasonable. The IRC method has found the minimum energy path, and the M06−2X curve of the IRC method (Figure S8, S13, S18) is smoother. In summary, M06−2X is reliable enough for our system [87]. Hence, M06−2X/6−31+g(d) && LANL2DZ is used for geometry optimization. Meanwhile, the single-point energies obtained from M06−2X/6−311+g(2df, p) && SDD can be used to get the energy change process of the whole reaction. According to theoretical calculations, the reaction process has two energy barriers. In the experiment, the cycloaddition reaction needs to be heated, which means that the reaction requires external heat to overcome two energy barriers. In an effort to gain mechanistic insight into the PO−CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst, We used DFT calculations for further theoretical studies. To illustrate its mechanism, a single repeating unit was chosen as the calculation model for simplicity. The optimal geometric arrangement of the reactant complexes was shown in Fig. 12 . The total relative energy of the substances (PO, CO2, and MIL-101-N (Bnme2) Br) was assumed to be zero. The formation of the intermediate (PO addition) was owing to the fact that the molecular of propylene oxide enters the open metal site (Cr) of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br and the bromide anion of the quaternary ammonium ionic liquid interacted with the beta carbon (βC) of the PO with an energy of -2.37 kcal mol−1. Simultaneously, the distance between the O atom of PO and the Cr atom of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br is 2.045 Å and the distance between the Br anion of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br and the beta carbon (βC) of the PO is 3.227 Å. In the later step, the distance between the Br anion of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br and the beta carbon (βC) of the PO is closer, it is 2.599 Å, forming the transition state (TS1) in the relative energy to +4.58 kcal mol−1. Thereby this step forming the TS1 is the rate-determining step. The cause that resulted in the Cr of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br to interact with the O atom of PO (Cr-O = 1.97 Å) is the transition from the intermediate (PO addition) to the transition state (TS1). It was found that the bond distance between βC and O of the propylene oxide was 1.769 Å. In the subsequent step, an intermediate (ring-opening) (-12.01 kcal mol−1) is formed, resulting in a stronger Cr-O bond (1.866 Å). Meanwhile, the bond (2.286 Å) between βC and O of the propylene oxide has been broken. When the total energy of the formed intermediate (CO2 insertion) is -3.03 kcal mol−1, the C atom of the CO2 molecule is close to the O atom of the propylene oxide (1.58 Å). The formation of the transition state (TS2) (7.02 kcal mol−1) resulted in a closer C(CO2)-O(PO) bond with bond distances of 1.46 Å. When the intermediate (Ring closure) (−18.04 kcal mol−1) is formed, the propylene carbonate is coming into being. In the final stage, the mixture of catalyst and propylene carbonate has a relative total energy of −3.58 kcal mol−1, which is the formation of propylene carbonate. The specific calculation information can be found in Supplementary Information. The reasonable mechanism of PC synthesis is shown in Scheme 4 . It is based on geometry optimization of MIL-101-N (Bnme2) Br and the experimental results. Initially, the activation of the epoxide ring was due to the interaction of chromium in the Lewis acid center of MIL-101-N (Bnme2) Br with the oxygen atom of PO. Concurrently, the bromide ions generated by IL carry out a nucleophilic attack on the β-carbon atom of the epoxide with less sterical hindrance, thereby promoting the ring-opening of the epoxide. Subsequently, the insertion of CO2 into the ring-opening intermediate. Finally, the corresponding cyclic carbonate is formed, and simultaneously closed and released by an intramolecular Br anion to regenerate the catalyst. After discussing the mechanism, it is found that the initial activation of the epoxide, the ring-opening formed during the reaction, and the stabilization of the carbonate intermediates all involve the overall role of the catalyst, which has an important effect on reducing the reaction time and reaction pressure. 4 Conclusion In summary, a new type of MOFs-based heterogeneous catalysts (MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br) was prepared using a simple hydrothermal method followed by amine-aldehyde condensation. Benefiting from the multi-functional synergistic effect of the active sites, MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst showed significantly enhanced activity for catalytic CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates compared with MIL-101-NH2 precursor. Under the optimized reaction conditions (1.4 MPa CO2 pressure, 17 mmol propylene oxide, 100 °C, 5 h, catalyst 0.93 mol%), a high yield (93 %) of PC along with 99 % selectivity was achieved, which is among the top levels for the PO−CO2 cycloaddition. More impressive, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst could be recycled simply by filtration and reusable for up to without a significant activity decay. Furthermore, our DFT calculations suggested that the cooperation between the coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ sites and Br− anions in MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br would lead to a pronounced catalytic activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. These study results highlight the potential of MOF materials decorated with ILs as high-performance heterogeneous catalysts for the preparation of cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: The reaction of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates requires high-performance, low-cost, and facilely recycled catalysts. Here, we report a heterogeneous catalyst (MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br) based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for catalytic CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates. The MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst was prepared as follows: A MOFs precursor (MIL-101-NH2) was firstly synthesized using a method of hydrothermal synthesis, then coupled with the quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquid (N(BzBnme2)Br) via aldehyde-amide condensation. A series of comparative experiments revealed that MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst has high activity for catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction to produce cyclic carbonates in the absence of solvents and co-catalysts. As was exampled by the synthesis of propylene carbonate, a high yield (93 %) and selectivity (99 %) was achieved under the optimized conditions (0.93 mol% MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst, 1.4 MPa CO2 pressure, 17 mmol propylene oxide, 100 °C, 5 h). More impressive, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst could be recycled easily by filtration and was reusable up to several times without a significant activity decay. Furthermore, our density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggested that such high catalytic activity mainly resulted from the cooperative catalysis between the coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ sites and Br anions in MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst. Meanwhile, a possible mechanism for the cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br catalyst was also proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Quaternary ammonium salt functionalized MIL-101-NH2(Cr) as a bifunctional catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates
